title: How much can an author copy from other authors’ book? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is really a legal question. There is such a thing as the doctrine of fair use. Under fair use, you can include certain passages, descriptions, and accounts as well as characters from another writer’s work in your. But you must specific credit to the writer, lyricist, research, or other creator of a work from which you are borrowing. But the rub here is, how much can you borrow from another writer without going on into copyright infringement? If you are self-publishing your work, then you need the advice of an attorney to make this kind of determination. If you are working with a publishing company, the company will be more aware of your concern than you could possibly be, and they will guide you accordingly. Always—ALWAYS—take their legal advice and counsel.

Zero. If you are making a new work of fiction, you can copy zero characters, fictional settings, and lines of text from that other book without permission. If you are making a non-fiction book, you can educate yourself on the topic by reading other non-fiction books, but you cannot copy any of their text, charts, or images without permission. Facts do not have copyright protection and you can clearly use facts known to anyone that has studied this subject. After all, there are how many books on the Paleo diet? If you are writing a book, stop worrying about this. It is already hard enough to write a book; most never complete it. When it comes time to turn your first draft into a publishable book, that’s when you work with an editor and publisher to make sure you are complying with copyright law.
